On 12 September 2012 23:33, Rob Marsden <rob@...> wrote:
>
>
> By definition, innovation is an ephemeral thing. It's very existence is
> its own nemesis. So if you reward for innovation, what is there to
> prevent the innovative streak, or the behaviour that was innovated, from
> being mutated away in future generations. As once the reward has been
> given for innovation, that behaviour ceases to earn a reward?

Rob,

Think of genomes as colonising new regions of the behaviour space. One
you find some new novel behaviour you really want to put a stake in
teh ground and leave some genomes there spawning offspring that will
move on to new behaviours. Just like in natural evolution where simple
organisms evolve to more complex ones, but a great many of the simple
organisms/strategies/behaviours are still valid because they don't
compete with the complex ones. E.g. mammals and bacteria co-exist
quite happily in the same world, and yet they are our ancient
ancestors in evolutiomary terms.

Colin
